column1: >> David

column3: and he's using that knowledge to make a decision. How is he using his knowledge to make a decision? What is the architecture? What is the reasoning that leads him to make that specific decision? This is one of the things we'll learn in this lesson. How might intelligent agents make complex decisions about the world?

column1: Before we talk about cognitive architectures in more detail
column2: first let us characterize what is a cognitive agent. Now
column3: there are many views of what a cognitive agent is. Here is one characterization of cognitive agent which is very popular in modern AI. A cognitive agent is a function that maps a perceptual history into an action. So it's B asterisk map into A where the asterisk on P stands for the history percepts. So this characterization says that one of the major tasks of cognitive agents is to select actions. You're driving a car. What action should you take next? You're having lunch
column4: what action should you do next? You're conversing with someone
column5: someone else
column6: what action should you do next? All the time we are taking actions
column7: we as humans. And the question is
column8: what should we do next? We base that action in part on the history of percepts in that particular situation. So this characterization captures the basic notion of cognitive agent in a very concise manner.

column1: The school of AI that works on cognitive architectures makes sort of fundamental assumptions about the nature of cognitive agents. First
column2: that cognitive agents are goal oriented
column3: or goal directed. They have goals and they take actions in the pursuit of those goals. Second
column4: that these cognitive agents live in a rich
column5: complex
column6: dynamic environments. Third
column7: this cognitive agent used knowledge of the world in order to pursue their goals in this rich complex dynamic environments. Fourth
column8: that this knowledge is particular abstraction that captures the important things about the world that the level of abstraction and removes all the details. And at that level of abstraction
column9: knowledge is captured in the form of symbols. Fifth
column10: the cognitive agents are very flexible. The behavior is dependent upon the environment. As environment changes
column11: so does the behavior. And sixth cognitive agents learn from their experiences. They're constantly learning as they interact with the world.

column1: We can capture the basic intuition behind work on cognitive architectures by a simple equation
column2: architecture plus content equals behavior. Let us look at this equation from two different perspectives. First
column3: imagine that you want to design an intelligent machine that exhibits a particular kind of behavior. This equation says that
column4: in order to do that
column5: you have to design the right architecture
column6: and then put the right kind of knowledge content into that architecture
column7: to get the behavior that you want from it. That's a complicated thing. But suppose that I could fix the architecture for you. In that case
column8: if the architecture is fixed
column9: I simply have to change the knowledge content to get different behaviors
column10: which is a really powerful idea. From a different direction
column11: suppose that we were trying to understand human behavior. Now we could say
column15: this behavior is arising because the knowledge content is different. We can map now
column16: behavior to content because the architecture is fixed. That simplifies our understanding of how to design machines or how to understand human cognition. By the way
column17: the same thing happens in computer architecture. I'm sure you have
column18: are familiar with computer architecture. Computer architecture has stored programs in it
column20: and that running of the stored program gives you different behaviors. The computer architecture doesn't change
column21: the stored program keeps on changing
column22: to give you different kind of behaviors. Same idea with cognitive architectures. Keep the architecture constant
column26: what is a good architecture? And that's what we'll examine later.

column1: So we have come across this high level architecture for deliberation earlier. Today we will talk about a specific cognitive architecture for deliberation. This architecture is called SOAR. I should mention that SOAR not only covers deliberation
column2: SOAR can also cover certain aspects of reaction
column3: and some aspects of meta cognition. But we are going to focus mostly on the deliberation component and so on. SOAR was initiated by Allen Neville
column4: John Lear
column5: and Paul Rosenbloom. And John Lear and Paul Rosenbloom have been working on it for the last 30 years or so. The highest level consists of a long term memory and a working memory. The [INAUDIBLE] itself contains different kinds of knowledge. In particular SOAR talks about three kinds of knowledge. Procedural
column6: semantic
column7: and episodic. Episodic knowledge has to do with events. Specific instances of events
column8: like
column9: what did you have for dinner yesterday. Semantic knowledge has to do with generalizations in the form of concepts and models of the world. For example
column10: your concept of a human being
column11: or your model of how a plane flies in the air. Procedural has to do with how to do certain things. So as an example
column12: how do you pour water from a jug into a tumbler. Notice that this makes an architecture. There are different components that are interacting with each other. This arrangement of components will afford certain processes of reasoning and learning. That's exactly the kind of processes of reasoning and learning that we'll look at next.

column1: So for this situation source cognitive architectures selected not one goal but to. So this SOAR theory this is called an impasse. An impasse occurs when the decision maker cannot make a decision either because not enough knowledge is available or because multiple courses of action there are being selected and the agent cannot decide among them. In this case two actions have been selected and the agent cannot decide between them. Should the pitch throw a curve ball or a fast ball? At this point SOAR will attempt to learn a rule that might break the impasse. If the decision maker has a choice between the fast ball and the curve ball and it cannot decide it
column2: might there be a way of learning a rule that decides between what to throw in a particular situation given the choice of the fast falling curve ball. For this now SOAR will invoke episodic knowledge. Let's see how SOAR does that and how it can help SOAR learn the rule that results in the breaking of the impasse. So imagine that SOAR had episodic knowledge about the previous event

column1: So how would you use a production system to design an agent that can solve Raven's Progressive Matrices. We could think about this kind of at two different levels. At one level we could imagine a production system that's able to address any incoming problem. It has a set of rules for what to look for in a new problem and it knows how to reply when it finds those things. But on the other hand

column3: it induces some production rules that govern the transformation between certain figures and then transfers that to other rows and columns. So in that way
